unnormalised: Imagine this: You’re in Chennai, it's 40 degrees Celsius outside, you’re sweating buckets after a hard day, and you’re just about to tuck into a plate of delicious biryani. The aroma is intoxicating. You reach for the remote to crank up the AC, and… *poof*… darkness. Welcome to the world of load shedding! Happens every darn time, doesn’t it? It feels like the universe is personally conspiring against your biryani enjoyment.

unnormalised: Basically, load shedding happens when the electricity supply isn’t enough to meet the demand. Think of it like this: your electricity company, say Tata Power in Mumbai, has a limited amount of electricity to distribute. If everyone starts blasting their ACs and using all their appliances at the same time, the system gets overloaded, and they have to deliberately cut off power to certain areas to prevent a total blackout. It's like a forced digital detox, whether you want it or not.

unnormalised: Now, you might be wondering why this keeps happening in 2024! Well, India’s power infrastructure is still catching up to its rapid economic growth and increasing energy needs. Plus, issues like coal shortages and delays in setting up new power plants can exacerbate the problem. Remember that whole Adani Power controversy back in 2022? Yeah, stuff like that doesn't help.

unnormalised: The worst part is how unpredictable it can be. Sometimes, it's scheduled, and your electricity company gives you a heads-up. Other times, it's completely random. You might be planning a big Onam celebration in Kerala, and suddenly, no lights! No cooking! No connecting with family via video call! Total chaos, I tell you.

unnormalised: Of course, there are solutions. Investing in renewable energy sources like solar and wind power is a big one. Improving the grid infrastructure to reduce transmission losses is crucial too. And maybe, just maybe, encouraging people to be a bit more mindful of their energy consumption.

unnormalised: But until then, we’re stuck with load shedding. So, what do we do? Get yourself a good UPS (Uninterruptible Power Supply) for your computer, invest in some rechargeable fans, and always keep a backup plan for your biryani. Because in India, you can never be too prepared for a power cut. And maybe, just maybe, pray to Indra, the God of rain and thunder, for a little bit of mercy. He owes us one. Rs. 500 says it will happen during the next IPL match.
